In summary, CITIOM entrusted its Aircraft to Gulfstream, the OEM, for a major inspection based on a proposal that proved to be grossly misleading in terms of cost and downtime. Gulfstream failed to utilize its own data and expertise to provide a realistic estimate, failed to properly manage the project, suffered from significant staffing and efficiency issues at its St. Louis facility, failed to adequately address corrosion issues from prior maintenance, and ultimately caused CITIOM significant financial and operational damages through extraordinary delays and cost overruns. Their failure to meet the repeatedly promised June 21, 2024 return date directly caused the collapse of a lucrative sale agreement, resulting in a further loss of approximately $1 million upon the eventual sale of the Aircraft.

results.query: What historical average downtime did Gulfstream's St. Louis facility have for similar inspections?
results.output:
CLAUDE CODE ANALYSIS
Query: What historical average downtime did Gulfstream's St. Louis facility have for similar inspections?

RELEVANT DOCUMENT EXCERPTS:

[Bassim Draft Witness Statement.docx, p.1]
Gulfstream did not provide an updated or revised Proposal after providing it in June 2023. I later learned that Gulfstream had introduced new data analytics capabilities in July 2023, designed to provide more accurate historical cost and downtime information for major inspections. However, Gulfstream did not use this tool to update our Proposal before we signed it in September 2023, nor before the Aircraft was inputted in January 2024. They failed to provide us with the benefit of this improved data.

[Bassim Draft Witness Statement.docx, p.1]
Gulfstream attempted to justify the delays and cost overruns by blaming unexpected corrosion findings and suggesting issues with the Aircraft's maintenance history or storage. I reject these excuses. As stated earlier, the Aircraft was well-maintained by Avcon, based at Farnborough (not a high-corrosion environment), washed regularly, and flown frequently (approx. 700 hours/year). Furthermore, Gulfstream, as the OEM with access to its own historical data and the specific maintenance history of this Aircraft (including the 144-month inspection and July 2023 work), should have anticipated the potential for corrosion and provided a realistic estimate from the outset. Their failure to do so, especially after introducing their new data analytics tool, constitutes a breach of their duty of care.

[Charles Philipp Outline #1.docx, p.1]
You did not include discrepancy repair time or costs, despite Gulfstream’s historical experience with scope growth.

[Charles Philipp Outline #1.docx, p.1]
You had access to Gulfstream historical maintenance records at the time?

[Charles Philipp Outline #1.docx, p.1]
Despite having historical data and newly developed analytics (July 2023), the quote was not revised.

Highlight absence of any historical data disclosure or warning in the customer-facing materials (GAC0000056)

Beauchemin described Gulfstream’s estimates as “within industry norms,” ignoring that Gulfstream’s own historical data showed wildly different averages.

historical results of operations for the years 2022 and 2023, as well as 2024 when

[Bassim Draft Witness Statement.docx, p.1]
In connection with the 144-month inspection, Gulfstream, at its Savannah facility, quoted approximately (as I recall) around $350,000 for the work, and 21-26 working days of downtime. [See NEW EXHIBIT: Gulfstream Proposal for Aircraft 144-Month Inspection dated September 20, 2019 at p. 12-13 of 14]. Ultimately, the 144-month inspection cost approximately $1 million, more than nearly three times the quote. This significant variance concerned me but was explained away at the time. [See NEW EXHIBIT: Gulfstream 144-Month Invoice dated June 9, 2020, at p.1]. [NOTE: Need to verify exact quote/invoice figures from exhibits vs. Bassim's recollection].

[Bassim Draft Witness Statement.docx, p.1]
I have always understood the estimates and quotes provided in the proposals to reflect estimates and quotes for all of the work required for the entire maintenance event. I expected that the quoted price covered the inspection and likely findings, perhaps with a reasonable variance of around 20% for unexpected issues. I did not understand the quote to be strictly for the inspection tasks alone, excluding all repair work for discrepancies found. Avcon recommended the Gulfstream US proposal based primarily on cost.

[Bassim Draft Witness Statement.docx, p.1]
Based on my previous experience with Gulfstream (including the 144-month variance), I understood the Proposal to contain an estimate of the downtime and costs associated with the 192-month inspection including the necessary work, allowing for some variability.

[7. Leonard B - Cross Exam & Impeachment.docx, p.1]
Ask if he reviewed Gulfstream’s July 2023 analytics tool or the data behind it.

[7. Leonard B - Cross Exam & Impeachment.docx, p.1]
Q: You know Gulfstream had access to internal analytics showing typical G550 inspections at St. Louis exceeded 100+ days?

[7. Leonard B - Cross Exam & Impeachment.docx, p.1]
Q: Are you aware Gulfstream rolled out a new downtime analytics tool in July 2023?

[Bassim Draft Witness Statement.docx, p.1]
Gulfstream did not provide an updated or revised Proposal after providing it in June 2023. I later learned that Gulfstream had introduced new data analytics capabilities in July 2023, designed to provide more accurate historical cost and downtime information for major inspections. However, Gulfstream did not use this tool to update our Proposal before we signed it in September 2023, nor before the Aircraft was inputted in January 2024. They failed to provide us with the benefit of this improved data.

[Bassim Draft Witness Statement.docx, p.1]
Gulfstream attempted to justify the delays and cost overruns by blaming unexpected corrosion findings and suggesting issues with the Aircraft's maintenance history or storage. I reject these excuses. As stated earlier, the Aircraft was well-maintained by Avcon, based at Farnborough (not a high-corrosion environment), washed regularly, and flown frequently (approx. 700 hours/year). Furthermore, Gulfstream, as the OEM with access to its own historical data and the specific maintenance history of this Aircraft (including the 144-month inspection and July 2023 work), should have anticipated the potential for corrosion and provided a realistic estimate from the outset. Their failure to do so, especially after introducing their new data analytics tool, constitutes a breach of their duty of care.

[2. Danny Farnham Direct Outline with Cross & Redirect.docx, p.1]
Should Gulfstream have used its July 2023 data analytics tool to revise or clarify those estimates?

[Closing Summary .docx, p.1]
Gulfstream’s own rebuttal expert never visited the facility. He never observed the work. He based his defense solely on internal documents and industry generalities. In contrast, CITIOM’s expert, Danny Farnham, was present on-site throughout the 10-month ordeal. He witnessed firsthand the mismanagement, the labor reassignments, the engineering indecision, and the chronic communication failures that defined this project.

[Closing Summary .docx, p.1]
This Tribunal has heard ample evidence that CITIOM acted in good faith. It selected Gulfstream precisely because of its OEM expertise, its access to historical inspection data, and its warranty support. CITIOM reasonably believed Gulfstream would be transparent and professional. Instead, it was misled—and made to bear the full cost of Gulfstream’s silence.

results.query: What is the timeline of expert report submissions?
results.output:
CLAUDE CODE ANALYSIS
Query: What is the timeline of expert report submissions?

RELEVANT DOCUMENT EXCERPTS:

[1. Bassim Haider Direct Outline with Redirect & Rehab.docx, p.1]
Theme: Gulfstream misrepresented scope and timeline, failed to disclose critical forecasting tools, and caused millions in foreseeable losses.

[1. Bassim Haider Direct Outline with Redirect & Rehab.docx, p.1]
What decisions did you make in reliance on Gulfstream’s timeline assurances?

[1. Bassim Haider Direct Outline with Redirect & Rehab.docx, p.1]
Were you ever told that the quoted timeline excluded major discrepancy work?

[1. Bassim Haider Direct Outline with Redirect & Rehab.docx, p.1]
Theme: CITIOM relied on Gulfstream’s timeline and escalated concerns when delays became apparent.

[4. Charles Philipp - Cross Exam & Impeachment .docx, p.1]
Strong Contradiction: Gulfstream's proposal gave CITIOM a timeline less than half of the known historical average—and you had the internal data to know better.

[4. Charles Philipp - Cross Exam & Impeachment .docx, p.1]
Isn’t it true that your quote gave the customer a timeline that was grossly misleading?

[4. Charles Philipp - Cross Exam & Impeachment .docx, p.1]
You had visibility into routing timelines?

[Joe Rivera Outline #1.docx, p.1]
What tracking mechanisms did he use to oversee critical project timelines and technician deployment?

[Joe Rivera Outline #1.docx, p.1]
Q: Would you agree that providing misleading timelines to the customer while deprioritizing their aircraft internally reflects a breakdown in management transparency?

[Bassim Haider Direct Outline with Redirect & Rehab.docx, p.1]
Theme: Mr. Haidar is an experienced, high-level international entrepreneur with decades of aviation and operational expertise.

[Report of Preliminary Hearing and Scheduling Order (002).docx, p.1]
Expert Discovery: The parties shall notify the Arbitrators on or before ________________ whether they will present any expert witnesses at the hearing. The Arbitrators shall set the schedule for expert discovery upon receiving notice of the presentation of expert witnesses from one or both parties.

[Report of Preliminary Hearing and Scheduling Order (002).docx, p.1]
Disclosures to the Arbitrators: Each counsel and party has a continuing obligation to protect the integrity of this arbitration proceeding by promptly providing the Arbitrators the information necessary to allow them to comply with their ongoing duties of disclosure. The parties and their counsel acknowledge their continuing obligation to supplement their disclosures of potential fact witnesses, expert witnesses, and any other individual or entity interested in the outcome of this arbitration proceeding. Any issues concerning disqualification of the Arbitrators should be raised promptly with CPR.

[Closing Summary .docx, p.1]
Gulfstream’s own rebuttal expert never visited the facility. He never observed the work. He based his defense solely on internal documents and industry generalities. In contrast, CITIOM’s expert, Danny Farnham, was present on-site throughout the 10-month ordeal. He witnessed firsthand the mismanagement, the labor reassignments, the engineering indecision, and the chronic communication failures that defined this project.

[Closing Summary .docx, p.1]
This Tribunal has heard ample evidence that CITIOM acted in good faith. It selected Gulfstream precisely because of its OEM expertise, its access to historical inspection data, and its warranty support. CITIOM reasonably believed Gulfstream would be transparent and professional. Instead, it was misled—and made to bear the full cost of Gulfstream’s silence.

Query: Do the expert reports identify contradictions in Gulfstream's methodology?

RELEVANT DOCUMENT EXCERPTS:

[Bassim Draft Witness Statement.docx, p.1]
Before the Aircraft was delivered to St. Louis, my pilot Mr. Schouten reached out to Mr. Danny Farnham for his assistance, as an owner's representative, in monitoring Gulfstream's service of the Aircraft. I first met Mr. Farnham in connection with the sale of the Challenger aircraft, and have known him for about seven years. He has also assisted me in connection with other aircraft maintenance events, including the 144-month inspection of this Aircraft at Gulfstream Savannah. I trust his expertise and diligence.

[Bassim Draft Witness Statement.docx, p.1]
In summary, CITIOM entrusted its Aircraft to Gulfstream, the OEM, for a major inspection based on a proposal that proved to be grossly misleading in terms of cost and downtime. Gulfstream failed to utilize its own data and expertise to provide a realistic estimate, failed to properly manage the project, suffered from significant staffing and efficiency issues at its St. Louis facility, failed to adequately address corrosion issues from prior maintenance, and ultimately caused CITIOM significant financial and operational damages through extraordinary delays and cost overruns. Their failure to meet the repeatedly promised June 21, 2024 return date directly caused the collapse of a lucrative sale agreement, resulting in a further loss of approximately $1 million upon the eventual sale of the Aircraft.

Gulfstream attempted to justify the delays and cost overruns by blaming unexpected corrosion findings and suggesting issues with the Aircraft's maintenance history or storage. I reject these excuses.
